data.title: CONTENTdm
data.meta_description:
James Cavanaugh interviews Patrick Lucey on April 18, 1985. Lucey discusses being state chair of the Democratic Party, the Democratic breakthrough in 1958, the role of the party in the 1960 presidential campaign and election, Lucey's support for John F. Kennedy, the Milwaukee County Democratic Party, relationships of elected Democrats to the party, disagreements and differences between Lucey and Gaylord Nelson, Lucey's election as lieutenant governor and his subsequent successful race for governor, the issue of sales tax during Governors Nelson and Reynolds' terms, Lucey's own accomplishments and disappointments as governor, his time as ambassador to Mexico, working for the Carter Administration, running for vice president with John Anderson, and thoughts on the Democratic Party of Wisconsin. Patrick Lucey served on the Wisconsin Assembly from 1949 to 1951, and was a candidate for Congress in 1950. He was the executive director of the Democratic Organizing Committee from 1951 to 52. He managed Tom Fairchild's campaign for senator in 1952, as well as Jim Doyle's campaign for governor in 1954. He served as the chair of Proxmire for Senate in 1957, and of the Democratic Party of Wisconsin from 1957 to 1963. He was also elected lieutenant governor, 1964. While he lost his bid for governor in 1966, he was elected governor and served from 1971 to 1977. Afterwards, he was appointed Ambassador to Mexico, 1977. He also ran for U.S. vice president in 1980 on the John Anderson presidential ticket.

This interview is part of the Wisconsin Democratic Oral History Project.
